B. A core is bonded with one thin-face sheet, providing a rigid, lightweight component

Questions.QuestionString: 42. How many main types of resin are used as a matrix?
43. Which factors have a positive effect on surface wetting?
Answers:
A. Removal of surface contamination, Viscosity reduction through application of heat, Time and
pressure at the bonding point.

B. Fingerprints left on adherent surfaces, Residues not removed from the adherent surfaces, Low
temperatures, Incorrect or no surface pre-treatment.
C. Removal of surface contamination, Time and pressure at the bonding point, Low temperatures

Questions.QuestionString: 44. Which factors have a negative effect on surface wetting?
Answers:
A. Removal of surface contamination, Viscosity reduction through application of heat, Time and
pressure at the bonding point.

B. Fingerprints left on adherent surfaces, Residues not removed from the adherent surfaces, Low
temperatures, Incorrect or no surface pre-treatment.
C. Removal of surface contamination, Time and pressure at the bonding point, Low temperatures

Questions.QuestionString: 45. Which of the following statements is correct about Scratch damage?
Answers:
A. Scratch is damage to a surface caused by scuffing, rubbing or scraping of the component. Fibres are
not damaged and mechanical performance is not affected.
B. Scratch is when a separation of materials, e.g. stringer to skin, occurs due to an adhesive failure

C. Scratch is the result of contact with a sharp object and only surface fibres are affected and the edges
are sharp

Questions.QuestionString: 46. Which of the following statements is correct about Abrasion damage?
Answers:
A. Abrasion is damage to a surface caused by scuffing, rubbing or scraping of the component. Fibres are
not damaged and mechanical performance is not affected.
B. Abrasion is when a separation of materials, e.g. stringer to skin, occurs due to an adhesive failure

C. Abrasion is the result of contact with a sharp object and only surface fibres are affected and the edges
are sharp

Questions.QuestionString: 47. Which of the following statements is correct about Lightning Strike damage?
Answers:
A. The effect of a lightning strike depends on the material will not be the same. For non-conductive
materials like Glass- and Aramid Fibre a large part of the component, if not completely protected, may
be blown out because both skins are affected and the core generally vapourised due to the extreme
heat

B. Lightning strike is when a separation of materials, e.g. stringer to skin, occurs due to an adhesive
failure

C. Lightning strike is when the separation of plies occurs in a multi-laminate material. This can be caused
by the material being hit (impact delamination), or when there is a resin failure for any other reason.

Questions.QuestionString: 48. Which of the following statements is correct about Dent damage?
Answers:
A. A dent is a deformity caused by extraneous forces, which are applied to the structure. This can be an
impact (FOD) for example.
B. A dent is when a separation of materials, e.g. stringer to skin, occurs due to an adhesive failure

C. A dent is when the separation of plies occurs in a multi-laminate material. This can be caused by the
material being hit (impact delamination), or when there is a resin failure for any other reason.

Questions.QuestionString: 49. Which of the following statements is correct about Erosion damage?
Answers:
A. Erosion is the result of contact with a sharp object and only surface fibres are affected and the edges
are sharp.

B. Erosion could affect all the leading edge surfaces, especially when the initial surface protection
system has been damaged. Erosion, when undetected or unrepaired, may generate composite
deterioration.

C. Erosion principally affects the resin and is generally due to accidental contact with aggressive
chemical liquids or products (e.g. hydraulic fluid).

Questions.QuestionString: 50. Which of the following statements is correct about Tap testing?
Answers:
A. Tap testing is only capable of finding flaws that are evident on the visible surface. Internal flaws in
composites (such as delamination, disbonding and matrix crazing) are not detectable. In addition, tight
surface cracks and edge delamination may not be detectable.

B. Tap testing is extremely sensitive in measuring small surface defects. The part to be inspected is
stressed by the application of heat, a static load or vibration to bring out the effect of the flaw on the
surface displacement

C. Tap testing is widely used for the quick evaluation of any accessible aircraft surfaces to detect
presence of debonding or entrapped water.

Questions.QuestionString: 51. What are the typical of repairs on Composite parts?
Answers: A. Injection repair, repair of edges.
B. Repair of coverings and honeycombs
C. Injection repair, repair of edges and repair of coverings, honeycombs

Questions.QuestionString: 52. Which of the following statements is correct about Repair through Injection of Resin?
Answers:
A. Repair through Injection of Resin is recommended for small damages of the honeycomb material. The
area is filled with thickened resin/hardener alloy and in the next step made plane. However, the
repaired area has lost nearly the half of its original strength.

B. The repair through injection of resin is an approved repair for delamination or dissolving adhesives. If
the damaged is caused by contamination or water absorption, this type of repair is not recommended.

C. Repair through Injection of Resin is typical for sandwich structures. It is easy to accomplish especially
if the damaged parts are very small. Today two different repairs of sandwich parts can be accomplished:
_ Repair of the covering, if only one side of the covering and/or parts of the combs are damaged.
_ Repair of the covering, if both covering parts and the combs are damaged

Questions.QuestionString: 53. Which of the following statements is correct about Filling Repair?
Answers:
A. Filling Repair Resin is recommended for small damages of the honeycomb material. The area is filled
with thickened resin/hardener alloy and in the next step made plane. However, the repaired area has
lost nearly the half of its original strength.

B. Filling Repair is an approved repair for delamination or dissolving adhesives. If the damage is caused
by contamination or water absorption, this type of repair is not recommended.

C. Filling Repair is typical for sandwich structures. It is easy to accomplish especially if the damaged parts
are very small. Today two different repairs of sandwich parts can be accomplished:
_ Repair of the covering, if only one side of the covering and/or parts of the combs are damaged.
_ Repair of the covering, if both covering parts and the combs are damaged

Questions.QuestionString: 54. Which of the following statements is correct about the Repair of honeycombs and covering?
Answers:
A. Repair of honeycombs and covering is recommended for small damages of the honeycomb material.
The area is filled with thickened resin/hardener alloy and in the next step made plane. However, the
repaired area has lost nearly the half of its original strength.

B. Repair of honeycombs and covering is an approved repair for delamination or dissolving adhesives. If
the damage is caused by contamination or water absorption, this type of repair is not recommended

C. Repair of honeycombs and covering is typical for sandwich structures. It is easy to accomplish
especially if the damaged parts are very small. Today two different repairs of sandwich parts can be
accomplished:
_ Repair of the covering, if only one side of the covering and/or parts of the combs are damaged.
_ Repair of the covering, if both covering parts and the combs are damaged

Questions.QuestionString: 55. What does Shelf Life mean?
Answers: A. Shelf Life is the length and time that a catalyzed resin will remain in a workable state

B. The shelf life is the time which the product is still good in an unopened container and varies from
product to product
C. The shelf life is the time that resin remains suitable for application after it has been mixed.

Questions.QuestionString: 56. What are the effects of the Perforated Parting Film?
Answers:
A. To prevent the bagging materials sticking to the repair surface. The film is perforated with small holes
to allow air and gases to escape from the repair piles. Some resin will escape through the holes so, for
repair, it is best to choose a film with pin-pricks to reduce the resin loss. Perforated parting film will
produce a shiny, resin-rich surface on the repair.

B. To help even-out the temperature over the entire repair, help even-out the pressure over the whole
repair and improve the flatness of the surface of the repair.
C. To allow the air and gases to escape easily

Questions.QuestionString: 57. What are the effects of the Breather Fabric?
Answers:
A. To prevent the bagging materials sticking to the repair surface. The film is perforated with small holes
to allow air and gases to escape from the repair piles. Some resin will escape through the holes so, for
repair, it is best to choose a film with pin-pricks to reduce the resin loss. Perforated parting film will
produce a shiny, resin-rich surface on the repair.

B. To help even-out the temperature over the entire repair, help even-out the pressure over the whole
repair and improve the flatness of the surface of the repair.
C. To allow the air and gases to escape easily

Questions.QuestionString: 58. What are the effects of the Peel Ply?
Answers:
A. To leave a rough finish. This produces a surface which can be painted or bonded without further
sanding.

B. To provide an easy path for air to escape and to absorb any resin which comes through the holes in
the perforated parting film.
C. To prevent resin soaking through onto the other bagging materials and the heater blanket.

Questions.QuestionString: 59. Basically, what is corrosion?
Answers:
A. Corrosion is defined as an undesirable, natural reaction of materials with substances in their
environment
B. Corrosion is defined as a desired chemical reaction of materials with substances in their environment
C. Corrosion is a type of mechanical abrasion that reduces material thickness

Questions.QuestionString:
60. If there is an area with worm-like traces on the surface of the aluminum alloy, what kind of
corrosion is it
61. Why is pitting corrosion dangerous
Answers:
A. Because it has no obvious signs on the surface of the metal so it is difficult to detect. In addition, the
corrosion extends in the vertical direction so it reduces material strength

B. Because it has no obvious signs on the surface of the metal so it is difficult to detect. In addition, the
corrosion extends in the horizontal direction so it reduces material strength
C. Because it is the most difficult type of corrosion to repair

Questions.QuestionString: 62. What are the basic conditions for the formation of corrosion?
Answers: A. Material, environment and the chemical reaction of material with environment
B. Material, inert gas and the chemical reaction of material with gas

Questions.QuestionString: 134. Why do aluminum alloys get hardened after a heat treatment process?
Answers:
A. The aluminum lattice structure gets distorted by precipitations formed by wandering foreign atoms
inside them.

B. The aluminum lattice structure gets uniformed by precipitations formed by wandering foreign atoms
inside them.

C. The aluminum lattice structure gets crystalized by precipitations formed by wandering foreign atoms
inside them.

Questions.QuestionString: 135. Which is not a valid temper designation?
136. Which of these materials are easiest to form with?

Answers: A. Solution annealed, quenched, stretched, straightened, artificially aged.
B. Solution annealed, quenched, straightened, stretched, artificially aged.

C. Soft annealing, solution annealing, quenched, stress relieved by compressing, naturally aged.

Questions.QuestionString: 143. The advantages of composite materials are:
Answers: A. High strength-to-weight ratio, Reduction of parts and fasteners, Reduction of wear, Easy to repair.

B. High strength-to-weight ratio, Reduction of parts and fasteners, Reduction of wear, Corrosion
resistance.

C. High strength-to-weight ratio, Reduction of parts and fasteners, Reduction of wear, Generally
expensive

Questions.QuestionString: 144. The disadvantages of composite materials are:
Answers:
A. Generally expensive. Not easy to repair; you need well-trained staff, tools, equipment and facilities to
repair composite components.

B. Generally expensive. Easy to repair; you need well-trained staff, tools, equipment and facilities to
repair composite components.

C. Generally cheap. Easy to repair; you don't need well-trained staff, tools, equipment and facilities to
repair composite components.

Questions.QuestionString: 145. What are film adhesives used for?

B. Bonding GFRP to AFRP and CFRP
C. Bonding sandwich core to GFRP, AFRP and CFRP

Questions.QuestionString: 157. When the matrix and the reinforcing material are combined and cured,
Answers: A. The part is weaker than the fabric is by itself, and weaker than the resin is by itself.
B. This condition would result in a weak product, and in extreme cases the epoxy would remain sticky.
C. The part is stronger than the fabric is by itself, and stronger than the resin is by itself.

Questions.QuestionString: 158. Which form are the matrix and the reinforcing generally in?
Answers: A. The matrix is generally in gas form and the reinforcing material is a solid
B. The matrix is generally in liquid form and the reinforcing material is a solid
C. The matrix is generally in solid form and the reinforcing material is a liquid

Questions.QuestionString: 159. Surface treatment of composite materials includes
Answers: C. Chromic Acid Anodizing (CAA) and Heat treatment

Questions.QuestionString: 160. Which type of resin is not currently utilized on composite structures?
161. Which type of damage is a skin not-perforated damage?
Answers: A. Abrasion, Lightning strike, Delamination, Scratches, Dents, Holes, Gouges
B. Abrasion, Debonding, Delamination, Nicks, Dents, Holes, Gouges
C. Abrasion, Debonding, Delamination, Nicks, Dents, Gouges, Scratches

Questions.QuestionString: 162. Which type of damage is a skin perforated damage (with damage of fibres)?
Answers: A. Abrasion, Delamination, Scratches, Dents, Gouges
B. Holes, Lightning strike, Impact by foreign object (FOD)
C. Abrasion, Debonding, Delamination, Nicks, Dents, Gouges, Scratches

Questions.QuestionString: 163. Which of the following statements is correct about Debonding damage?
Answers:
A. Debonding is damage to a surface caused by scuffing, rubbing or scraping of the component. Fibres
are not damaged and mechanical performance is not affected.
B. Debonding is when a separation of materials, e.g. stringer to skin, occurs due to an adhesive failure

C. Debonding is the result of contact with a sharp object and only surface fibres are affected and the
edges are sharp

Questions.QuestionString: 164. Which of the following statements is correct about Delamination damage?
Answers:
A. Delamination is a deformity caused by extraneous forces, which are applied to the structure. This can
be an impact (FOD) for example.
B. Delamination is when a separation of materials, e.g. stringer to skin, occurs due to an adhesive failure

C. Delamination is when the separation of plies occurs in a multi-laminate material. This can be caused
by the material being hit (impact delamination), or when there is a resin failure for any other reason.

Questions.QuestionString: 165. Which of the following statements is correct about Chemical Degradation damage?
Answers:
A. Chemical degradation is the result of contact with a sharp object, only surface fibres are affected and
the edges are sharp.

B. Chemical degradation could affect all the leading edge surfaces. Chemical degradation, when
undetected or unrepaired, may generate composite deterioration.

C. Chemical degradation principally affects the resin and is generally due to accidental contact with
aggressive chemical liquids or products (e.g. hydraulic fluid).

Questions.QuestionString: 166. What testing methods can detect the presence of debonding and delamination damages?
Answers: A. Tap Testing, Visual or optical inspection

Questions.QuestionString: 167. Which of the following statements is correct about Radiography testing?
Answers: A. Radiography is only capable of finding flaws that are evident on the visible surface.

B. The part to be inspected by radiography is stressed by the application of heat, a static load or
vibration to bring out the effect of the flaw on the surface displacement.
C. Radiography is a NDT technique that uses X-rays or gamma rays.

Questions.QuestionString: 168. Which of the following statements is correct about Ultrasonics testing?
Answers:
A. Ultrasonic waves travel through solids and liquids at relatively high speeds, but are rapidly attenuated
in gasses. The density and the elasticity of the medium may affect the wave speed.

B. The part to be inspected by ultrasonics is stressed by the application of heat, a static load or vibration
to bring out the effect of the flaw on the surface displacement.
C. Ultrasonics is a NDT technique that uses X-rays or gamma rays.

Questions.QuestionString: 169. A category of plastic material that is capable of softening or flowing when reheated is called?
170. The length and of time that a catalyzed resin will remain in a workable state is called the
171. What is the purpose of the water break test?
Answers: A. Make sure the repair surface is clean of grease and contamination
B. Ensure that there is no further damage at the repair surface

C. Make sure the repair surface is clean of grease and contamination and no further damage at the
repair surface

Questions.QuestionString: 172. What are the effects of the Caul Plate?
Answers:
A. To prevent the bagging materials sticking to the repair surface. The film is perforated with small holes
to allow air and gases to escape from the repair piles. Some resin will escape through the holes so, for
repair, it is best to choose a film with pin-pricks to reduce the resin loss. Perforated parting film will
produce a shiny, resin-rich surface on the repair.

B. To help even-out the temperature over the entire repair, help even-out the pressure over the whole
repair and improve the flatness of the surface of the repair.
C. To allow the air and gases to escape easily

Questions.QuestionString: 173. What are the effects of Non-Perforated Parting Film?
Answers:
A. To leave a rough finish. This produces a surface which can be painted or bonded without further
sanding.

B. To provide an easy path for air to escape and to absorb any resin which comes through the holes in
the perforated parting film.
C. To prevent resin soaking through onto the other bagging materials and the heater blanket.

Questions.QuestionString: 174. What are the effects of the Bleeder Cloth?
Answers:
A. To leave a rough finish. This produces a surface which can be painted or bonded without further
sanding.

B. To provide an easy path for air to escape and to absorb any resin which comes through the holes in
the perforated parting film.
C. To prevent resin soaking through onto the other bagging materials and the heater blanket.

Questions.QuestionString: 175. What are the effects of the Heater Blanket?
Answers:
A. Heater Blanket is used to control the temperature of the repair during the warm-up, cure and cool
down stages of the repair
B. Heater Blanket is used to reduce heat loss and to minimise the effects of draughts on the repair
C. Heater Blanket is used to seal the vacuum bag to the surface of the item under repair

Questions.QuestionString: 176. What are the effects of the Insulation?
Answers:
A. Insulation is used to control the temperature of the repair during the warm-up, cure and cool-down
stages of the repair
B. Insulation is used to reduce heat loss and to minimise the effects of draughts on the repair
C. Insulation is used to seal the vacuum bag to the surface of the item under repair

Questions.QuestionString: 177. What are the effects of the Bag Seating Tape?
Answers:
A. Bag Seating Tape is used to control the temperature of the repair during the warm-up, cure and cool
down stages of the repair
B. Bag Seating Tape is used to reduce heat loss and to minimise the effects of draughts on the repair
C. Bag Seating Tape is used to seal the vacuum bag to the surface of the item under repair

Questions.QuestionString: 178. When you immerse a electrode metal bars in electrolyte fluid, what will happen with the Anode?
Answers:
A. The dissolved ions take in electrons and deposit as metal atoms on the electrode surface, which
means that the metal ions are reduced
B. This is an oxidation-reduction reaction

C. Positively charged metal-ions are emitted to the electrolyte, and leave behind negatively charged
electrodes in the metal

Questions.QuestionString: 179. When you see the white-grey powdery on surface of steel, what does it mean?
Answers: B. This is a sign of corrosion on surface
C. This is the production of the oxidation on steel surface

Questions.QuestionString: 180. What will happen if Austenitic steel works under high temperature?
Answers: A. It can lose their corrosion resistance ability
B. Steel characteristics do not change, due to their high thermal strength

Questions.QuestionString:
181. Can steels made from alloys of chromium (Cr)-nickel (Ni) and chromium-nickel-manganese be
corroded?
Answers: A. No, They are corrosion resistance steels
B. Yes, if it works under high temperature environment
C. Yes, after hardened only by cold-working

Questions.QuestionString: 182. Aluminum alloy has good corrosion resistance right?
Answers: C. It depends on the main metal in the alloy

Questions.QuestionString: 183. With aluminum alloys are used on aircraft, which part plays the role of corrosion resistance
Answers: A. The main metal composition in the alloy will determine its corrosion resistance
B. Due to the low strength of aluminium alloy, it is unsuitable for aircraft structures
C. A thin layer of pure aluminium on surface is a means of corrosion protection

Questions.QuestionString: 184. Why say Corrosion of metals is the tendency to return to their natural state?
Answers: A. Because in nature metals exist in the form of alloys

B. Because in nature, almost all metals exist in the form of noble metals, thus alloys tend to return to
their metal oxides form

C. Because in nature, except some noble metals, almost metals do not exist in their pure form, exist only
in the form of metal ores (oxides)

Questions.QuestionString: 185. In a mechanical joint between aluminum alloy and copper, which material will be corroded first
Answers: A. None of them, because they are corrosion resistance

Questions.QuestionString: 186. Why aircraft fuselage structure joints use aluminum alloy rivets and not steel or monel rivets?
Answers: A. Because aluminum alloy rivets are easy to install
B. Because aluminum alloy rivets have better strength and less susceptible to corrosion than others
C. This will minimize corrosion due to the dissimilar metal of rivets and aircraft structures

Questions.QuestionString: 187. When there is corrosion on aircraft structures, what are its consequences ?
Answers:
B. Aircraft structures are reduced mechanical strength, functional impairment or destroyed if these
damaged structures are not repaired appropriately
C. The aircraft is not allowed to operate until the damaged structures are replaced

Questions.QuestionString: 188. Pin (threaded) fasteners are usually installed in interference-fit holes ?

189. A clearance fit hole (unless specified differently) must be used if one or more of the structural
members to be attached are made of ?
190. When blind rivets which are used for repair work on the aircraft ?
Answers: A. At the locations in an aircraft structure, which are need the heavy load
B. At the locations in an aircraft structure, which are need the light load

C. At the locations in an aircraft structure, which are very hard to reach for riveting - it is impossible to
set a rivet snap at the other site of the rivet

Questions.QuestionString: 191. Which type of solid rivet may used in tank sealing rivets ?

B. Type A- and AD rivets
C. Type AD- and DD rivets

Questions.QuestionString: 192. Which type of fit are used to install Lockbolt pins in thin structure ?

195. A commonly-used rule of thumb for selecting the rivet size is to choose a rivet whose diameter is
?

B. At least 2.5 times the thickness of the thickest sheet being joined.
C. At least 3 times the thickness of the thickest sheet being joined.

Questions.QuestionString: 196. Symbol of solid rivet 2017 Aluminium Alloy (AD) ?

Questions.QuestionString: 197. Symbol of solid rivet 2017 Aluminium Alloy (D) ?

B. A small dimple in the centre of their head
C. A raised dot in the centre of their head.

Questions.QuestionString: 198. Symbol of solid rivet 2024 Aluminium Alloy (DD) ?
Answers: A. A raised dot in the centre of their head.

C. They are identified by two raised dashes on their heads.

Questions.QuestionString: 199. Symbol of Titanium rivets are identified on their head ?
Answers: A. Titanium rivets are identified by a raised V or T on their head

Questions.QuestionString: 200. Symbol of Corrosion Resistant Steel rivets are identified on their head ?

Questions.QuestionString: 201. The MS-Fitting consists of?

Questions.QuestionString: 227. What is definition of thermocouple correct?
Answers:
A. The thermocouple consists of two different metal alloys soldered or welded together in which a
minimal electrical potential is created when the wiring contact is heated which is proportional to the
temperature

B. The thermocouple consists of two different metal alloys soldered or welded together in which a
minimal electrical potential is created when the wiring contact is heated which is inversely proportional
to the temperature

C. The thermocouple consists of two different metal alloys soldered or welded together in which a
minimal electrical potential is created when the wiring contact is heated which is proportional to the
humidity

Questions.QuestionString: 228. What is a function of Coaxial cables?
Answers: B. For the transmission of high-frequency signals
C. For the transmission of low-frequency signals

Questions.QuestionString: 229. What elements do the current capacity of wires depend on?

B. The insulation and the wire size

Questions.QuestionString: 277. In a Galvanic Cell made from Zn (Anode) and Cu (Cathode), which electrode is oxidized

280. During routine aircraft maintenance, a fuel sample is usually taken for inspection. One of the
purposes of this is to prevent corrosion in the fuel tank. Why?
Answers:
A. Because in the fuel tank may have water and microorganisms can grow in the tank. This will cause
corrosion of the fuel tank structure

B. Because the fuel in the tank can be mixed with the electrolyte solution, leading to electrochemical
corrosion

C. Because the fuel in the tank can change its chemical structure, turning it into structural corrosive
substances

Questions.QuestionString:
281. In 2 metal joints:
1: between aluminum alloy 2024 and tin,
2: between 2024 and Zinc.

Answers: A. In the joint between 2024 and Tin
B. In the joint between 2024 and Zinc
